comments.text: Just out of curiosity, what motors/escs are you flying this with?
comments.author: nog3

comments.text:
Hey nog3,
I'm using the Rotorgeek ESC's
30A (they're a little bit bigger than the usual 12A).
This is the reason for the 3D printed parts.
The 30A ESC won't fit in the back compartment for the 3rd back motor.
The Motors are Sunnysky 2207s 2100KV spinning 6" Props.
This set up is supposed to push 950-1000 grams of thrust per motor X 3 =
That's close to 3000 grams of thrust, all I have to do is keep the Trifecta under 1000 grams
And I'll have it in the 3 to 1 ratio!
Great power system!
Also:
Naze32
Taranis

author: hylpro

description.text:
A little train that can be personalized with your child's name, or age.  (Would be a fun decoration surrounding the birthday cake at a party.)  
Can print as many cars as you need. Letters are printed separately and dropped into the shallow cars.  There's a deeper car that can be filled with a few candies.  
Please reference the Instructions for tips on printing.

These parts slide into place, and are glued. Some parts need to be printed with minimal support. The glue pegs on this thing tend to run tight. You might prefer to use wooden matchsticks with epoxy instead of printing the wheel connector pegs. Or plan to sand/trim them just a bit - having them too loose made the wheels unstable - these are deliberately tight to keep the wheels aligned and allow them to turn. (What I found that worked extremely well was to just crimp the round ends of the pegs a bit with pliers before inserting and gluing them. Saved a lot of time.) The wheel pegs are attached first to the car from the square side, then the wheels are put on over the pegs, then the end caps on the round end of the peg. The engine boiler slides onto the base, the cab is snapped into place into the groove behind the boiler (and seated all the way down) and then the cowcatcher rod slides through the boiler into the cab. The holes will need to be aligned. You will need to glue the roof on the engine cab, but the caboose roof can be left unattached so you can put a little gift in it.
Other glue points are the connectors and end-caps on the wheels.

description.text:
Triple Junction unit
and twin units in double locked linkage

This is a simple enclosure that I designed for an Arduino Duemilanove (USB).
The "top" part slides into the bottom one. The one I printed has enough friction that I didn't need any glue to hold the two parts together, yet they can still be taken apart when needed.
There is a hole on the side opposite from the USB port through which you can put cables. There are also two holes in the top part that I used for a led and a push-button. Those can be easily commented out if not needed.
Print both parts.

title: Thing-O-Matic X-Axis Follower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The default ToM X-axis is over constrained, so it has a lot of friction and can bind. The belt retainer is also less than elegant. This fixes both problems with one printed part and two small bearings. This thing replaces one pair of the slide bearings on either the HBP or the ABP with a pair of small ball bearings and provides a better clamp for the belt. This fixes a most of the skipped X axis steps issues and lets you move at up to 100mm/sec! This thing is derived from the work of Ed at http://softsolder.com/2011/04/10/thing-o-matic-x-axis-rod-follower/ I did a small amount of work to his original script for easier printing. Ed puts out a huge amount of great upgrade work for the ToM, check him out! Shameless Plug:

If you have a couple of 693 bearings, just print the attached stl and install in your x-axis after removing the slide bearings from the belt side and belt holder clips.  Otherwise adjust the OpenSCAD script for whatever small bearings you have.  All of the adjustable bits are well commented, so you can easily make it fit whatever setup you have.

comments.text: This thing was a massive improvement to my ToM. It completely resolved the over-constraint on my x-axis and I now get perfect prints. Thanks!
comments.author: nhand42

comments.text: "replaces one pair of the slide bearings"

comments.text: I guess for one side you want a slide-bearing.

comments.author: bstott

comments.text: I don't have Inventor, AutoCAD or anything of that sort.  OpenSCAD only exports 2D drawings to dxf, so this can't be exported there.  But, the STL is available for download which can be used in just about anything, including RepG for printing.  What is it that you need?
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: I'm wanting to incorporate this onto a print of the strut. Mine was broken when I first assembled the bot and now I've got a build for the part. I thought I could incorporate this and just print one part.  :-D OpenSCAD does 3D but only exports/saves in 2D? I can use Heeks, ProgeCAD - Not sure what others.
comments.author: carmiac

comments.text: OpenSCAD is really only designed to create STL's.  I don't really know much about the DXF export capabilities other than that it is in the menu list.  STL is format of choice in the 3D printing world as far as I can tell.  If you would just like to mash them up, check out MeshLab.
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: Just thinking - what is the size of 639 bearings - i cant guess it ...
comments.author: Joakim

comments.text: 693's are 3x8x4 (inner, outer, width)
comments.author: Joakim

comments.text: Thats for 693ZZ's, actually.  If you have unshielded 693's, they are 3x8x3
comments.author: carmiac

comments.text: What's the reason for doing this on the belt side of the X-axis and not on the other side (which is further away from the belt)? On the Y-axis the follower is on the side furthest away from the belt. Why not do the same for the X-axis? Would that not result in even less friction?
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: The two sides aren't symmetrical: I wanted to put it back there, too, but there's basically no clearance between the rod and the plywood. (Note the comment at the top of the code, where it says "rear"... sigh.)
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: I think that if the X axis had a larger mass or the rods were spaced further apart like in the Y axis, it probably would be worth it to put this on the other side.
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: This takes the friction down to almost unmeasurable levels.  At least, unmeasurable with the tools either Ed or I have.
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: Hi, How is the belt going to wear out at the clamp? There is no real movement. And just to voice an observation. I've seen other contraptions with the belts cut and clamped. We could do this to take out an inch of slack and give us more room for adjustment on the motor? Just a thought. I'm not ready to tear mine apart - again. :-)

description.text: You're probably like me : always trying to fix or improve something on your 3D printer, which means that quite often you have to do stuff inside the box, under the printing plate. The printing plate is great. I mean, for supporting the stuff you print. But when you have to check a connection, roll a cable or find that tiny nut that fell down, it's kind of annoying when it's in the way. This plate holder will save your nervous system : put it on the lower steel bar of your X axis, lift the printing plate manually (all motors being off, of course), then put the plate holder lower hook right under it. Then you're free of your movements. :) IMPORTANT : remember to remove it before you restart your printer, or you'll be sorry (not my fault, you've been warned)! You might be interested in the bed plate clips that you also see on the photographs? I've shared them too, so you can get them right here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:843865! ;) PS : depending on your own setup (the hot end height, for instance) you might have to adapt this piece's length.

Milad Tower , also known as Tehran Tower, is a multi-purpose Iranian concrete tower built in 2007 in between the Shahrak-e Gharb and Gisha districts of Tehran. It stands at 435 m (1,427 ft) from base to the tip of the antenna. The head consists of a large pod with 12 floors, the roof of which is at 315 m (1,033 ft). Below this is a staircase and elevators to reach the area. Milad Tower location on center of map in dark blue
Milad Tower is the sixth tallest tower in the world after the Tokyo Skytree, Canton Tower in Guangzhou, CN Tower in Toronto, Ostankino Tower in Moscow, the Oriental Pearl Tower in Shanghai. It is also the 17th tallest freestanding structure in the world.

title: Enclosure for BlinkM i2c-controlled RGB led

description.text: This is an enclosure that I made for the BlinkM RGB led from ThingM - http://blinkm.thingm.com/.

There are 4 parts to print, I assembled them in the following way: [box.stl] [top.stl] (diffuser) [plate.stl] (BlinkM) [back.stl] I spray-painted in white the diffuser-facing side of the plate part. I attached the BlinkM to the other side of the plate with hot glue -> the led must be centered under the diffuser, and the 4 pins must go through the hole in the "back" part. For the diffuser I used a ball which I cut in half from a roll-on deodorant like this one: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Deoroller_DB.jpg There should be a small space between the floor and the rear part of "back.stl" so that you can put double-sided adhesive tape under it to attach the light wherever you need it.

comments.text: Deodorant ball as light diffuser, brilliant. I've got one that I can now save from the recycling bin! Reduce, reuse, recycle. Cool  8-)

This is an experimental 3d printable rotary rolamite bearing. Being experimental it hasn't been printed or tested yet. It is based on the design found here(SEE FIGURE 16): http://www.rexresearch.com/wilkes/1wilkes.htm If you print this out please give me feedback on how well it works or if you're feeling really generous send one to me...

What you need: RTV sealant grade silicone(though should work with other types of silicone too.), a short length of M8 studding(optional), some M8 bolts(optional).
Step 1: print all parts, print six of the parts named rolamite_roller_print_six.stl, and one of every other part.
Step 2: Mold the flexible silicone band. Fill the channel in the part named rolamite_band_mold1.stl with silicone, be careful not to create any bubbles in the silicone when you do this. Next either scrape the excess silicone off the top with the back of a knife as you would when measuring out a cup of flour, or put rolamite_band_mold2.stl onto it and apply pressure. One way of doing this is to put M8 studding through the hole in the molds, put two nuts on the end of it, and tighten. Or you could use clamps or something heavy.
Step 4: After the silicone has finished curing, carefully remove the flexible silicone band from the mold by going around the edges with a toothpick. Trim excess silicone.
Step 5: assemble parts according to picture.

comments.text: Gene
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ran across rolamite several years ago but have never found much in real life. I am interested in using it to drive the X and Y axis for an laser engraver 4' by 4'. Anyone ever use it in real world? [email protected]

comments.text: I had an idea for an alternate configuration. this would require 3 bands and possibly grooves in the rollers for them to sit in but would enable a larger shaft diameter with the same diameter bearing.
comments.author: richard

comments.text: Look interesting, but although three rollers are nicely cinched in and won't slip, the other three are not cinched in and will slip. Also there is only point-contact with the outer race so that under load, the inner mechanism as a whole will slide against the inner surface of the outer race. The Patent for the Rotary Rolamite might be worth looking at. A video, a hugely detailed descriptive document and the patent are all available for viewing at http://www.ErikBrinkman.com/Scroller/Home.htmlhttp://www.ErikBrinkman.com/Sc...
comments.author: Erik

comments.text: In the real Rotary Rolamite (ScrollerWheel), all the rollers are cinched in.
comments.author: Erik

comments.text: We'll see how this works once it's printed. At this point, I'm more worried about the silicone band stretching causing slipping. This can be solved by integrating nylon fiber into the band. Also this bearing is intended for a printable stepper motor that fits on to reprap Darwin. In order to make a stepper motor that fits on reprap Darwin, the bearing has to be small. I don't think it would be possible to make a bearing like that would fit into my printable stepper motor design.

description.text:
Made a little script that carves slices every 3mm (with a 1/2 mm gap) out of cylinder from which the clock's negative space has been removed via the difference() command.
The negative space is imported as an STL file, and was made using the new negative space feature of version 4 of the clockwork library.
Includes pre-visualization via the # debug modifier in OpenCSG mode (see jpg for example).
If there is some interest, I can clean up the code for the slicer and pack it up into a library?

Pick a slice thickness, a gap thickness, and choose the slice you want to output, using F5 (OpenCSG) for a quick render with a ghost-view of the negative space.
Once you are happy, render using F6 and export the STL.
Note that for this frame to actually work, the negative space needs two things added: the actual metal shafts, and some space for the string to run down from the drum. I'll make the necessary changes to the clock script.

Tired of getting a 10 hour print and your extruder ruined by a spool getting tangled? even attended prints can get ruined in 30 seconds since you don't always notice the tangle before the filament stops flowing resulting in an air print. The anti tangle system (ATS) is a set of printable parts that put your rep2 into cold pause whenever there is a tangle. see it in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DEAy2hf6FU0 print the parts, add a piece of cord (fishing line works well). the ATS works by moving a lever that presses the hardware pause button if a tangle happens. you can then solve the tangle or change filament, unpause the machine, and enjoy a saved print. Update : you can use http://jettyfirmware.yolasite.com/v74-v44.php#pstop the new sailfish to add a p_stop switch and use only the back assembly. however for the rep2 the jetty team hasn't figured out the P-stop yet. so we're waiting for that.

print all the parts, 2 bottom clips and 4 of the pins. assemble the lever mount with the 2 lever arms and the filament guide like in the pics using 2 pins. assemble the button pusher & button pusher clip with a pin remove the filament tube guide and the black wires guide from the back of the replicator, and insert the lever mount in place from below. it should hold fast. load filament thru the lever assembly and insert the tube guide into the top of the filament guide like in the pics. insert the wire holder & guide above the mount. clip on the 2 bottom clips as shown in the pics thread a cord from the lever, thru the wire holder guide, back thru the lever mount, and thru the 2 bottom clips, up the front and tie it to the button pusher. the lever should be in a 90 degree position more or less when the bot is working properly, and the button pusher should rest softly on the front button with the cord almost tight. you can insert a pin into the middle hole in the lever assembly to make sure the lever doesnt drop as a safety measure when you don't want the ATS to work. Operation:
when not using the ATS, you can slide the front assembly to the left to get it out of the way, and insert the safety pin. when using, remove the pin, and place the button pusher over the bot button. start your print, and choose the cold pause option (or pause, if you don't have sailfish) if and when a tangle happens, the lever will start moving towards the spool. after about 45 degrees (it takes a few seconds) the cord will pull the button pusher and depress the button. testing: using filament load, manually stop the spoll from turning and test to see if the ATS presses the button to stop the loading. see it in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DEAy2hf6FU0 notes:
  • I used plain pins. should work well.
  • there is a stop on the button pusher so it can't depress the button too hard if you worry about the button being damaged.
    • if you install - please send me a note when it saves you from a tangle :)

  • moved the attachment holes to inside the butterfly's wings

    • Also prints very nice when doing a material swap after the first 4 layers, as for instance in ericchf's design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:552835/

Slice at 0,1mm I used an Ultimaker original with 123inkt's purple filament, switched to black after the 4th layer.

so the leg (the spring really) of my glasses broke off and after 2 weeks of no replacement (no contact from the factory that made em, or so I'm told by my optician) I printed a replacement.
I know glasses have been printed before but I needed my lenses to fit in them so... yeah. I did not add stand-offs for on the nose yet but I'm already wearing them so I figured I'd post it anyway
I intended to have printed hinges in the design but they have not come loose and would probably be a bit fragile if they do come loose so I'll have to change that a bit. for the next iteration. I modelled the frame in solidworks with photo references, I modelled the holder for the glasses separately from the frame (as that was also a separate part in the original frame) added in some support as the generated support is way more difficult to remove. this frame is slightly less bulky than other frames I think as it was based on a metal frame not a plastic one. I think we/someone should make something where you can put a vector-graphic of the glasses outline with perhaps a center point in and generate the glasses with some settings for width of face etc...

printed with no support (ecept that wich is designed in), one perimiter and 70% fill.  
the bottom of the glasses (top bit during print) came ot pretymuch OK there was a very tiny bit of droop in the bridge, not as much as I had expected.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/e453qvt6jSl

RGB LED "Mega"star for my upcomming Christmas show :-)
This star contains 146 addressable WS2812B RGB LEDs. This star will sit on top of our "MegaTree". (christmas tree with about 7100 addressable RGB LEDs in it)
It measures approx. 50 cm in diameter (that's about 20" for my American friends)
Printable on a standard 20cm (8") heatbed.
Pieces can be connected with M4 nuts/bolts. Here is a small video of the star in action, with the default Adafruit neopixel library test:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=68AvOlbgXvE

Needed prints: 1x middle-bottom
1x middle-top
5x wing-bottom
5x wing-top connect pieces together with M4 nuts/bolts,
and glue LEDstrips in, so the LEDs face "outward" the sides of the star. outer ring = 50 LEDs, next ring = 40 LEDs, next ring = 30 LEDs, inner ring = 20 LEDs, inner star = 5 LEDs, inner-hole = 1 LED
(you need to make holes for the wires yourself, depending on how you want to connect the different LEDstrips) Next, text the LEDs, and glue the middle-top in place.
After this, glue the 5 wing-top pieces in place ... Enjoy :-)

comments.text:
Hello, I printed the stars in PLA, no color, the material is called "natural PLA".
(it's also comes by the name "transparant PLA", but is is actually some milky white half look-trough look ...)
Take a look at my other designs (my small stars and my leaping arches, you will find some clear pictures of the printed material within those designs)

title: TOM X-Axis Follower - Recessed Bearing Bolts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: NOTE: I ended up switching to this follower instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8625 It works quite nicely. Added a recess on the back side to insert the bearing bolt heads into. That way you can put nuts on the bearing side to keep them secure instead of relying on drilling/tapping the plastic. I also made the default for the dimensions of 693 bearings. The comments in the scad script show you what to change for whatever bearings you have. Note: 624 bearings are too large! So anything under that should work.
Buy some 693 bearings on ebay for about 5 bucks, remove bushings on the belt side, attach this thing, enjoy smoother motion!

This motor is like the others but I had added a extra Drum this is for the self contain generator.This is what inspired me https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sAIG0-lNSEs The coils for the generator came from a pancake motor from out of a ceiling fan. Woks well for the job. I added a bridge rectifier and a 12 volt reg. and hooked to a DC to AC riveter for my regulated 110 ~ 120 VAC. out. This is still a work in progress I have been working on researching and gathering all the info from different sources for the last three years. Not to mention learning to create things in the 3d world. Oh by the way the program I used that I created my parts with is very similar to Solid Works, Please take a look at this 9 min. video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZXgMY3-hlgs But this is FREE it's name is Design Spark Mechanical http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical .I started out with Blender for about a year but when I came across DSM I was blown away. What I had learned in blender for the year or so, I had
learned in 3 ~ 4 hours in DSM I highly recommend it. Please if you have any questions or input, my E-Mail [email protected] :)

comments.author: nasrullah

comments.text:
Their are 20 magnets on the outside ring and 17 on the inside disk. The size of the magnets are 5mm. Diam. x 10mm.Long. I had printed this on a Prusa pro C.The size of the magnets for the generator are 10mm. Diam. X 5mm. Long.When using a pancake coil from a ceiling fan I get about 27 Volts A.C. Also in response to YomGui I do not know were you got the idea that their are 8 magnets anywhere in my design.
Good luck.
Note this is a very touchy device, It took me over a month to get mine to work..
Also when mounting the disk use 1/2 washers and Coupling Connector Nuts at 25mm. long. This is because of the pitch of the threads. With a shorter length nut it tents to give the disk a wobble or an alignment issue not 90 deg. to shaft, the longer Coupling Connector deals with this issue. These are what I had used. https://www.amazon.com/a16050300ux0577-Connector-Stainless-Threaded-Coupling/dp/B01IVT9DT0/ref=pd_sbs_60_8?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=B6NA3HD1VVEH8TMV6R34

author: gapjerjer

title: Nema 17 Cable Chain Brackets for ShapeOko

description.text: I needed a way to connect RotoScan's cable chain to my ShapeOko.  These brackets clip onto the X and Y steppers to provide a simple connection point for the cable chain.

Print 1 "bracket 1" for each Y stepper motor.  Print 1 "bracket 2" for the X stepper.  Laser cut the X cable chain/belt end brackets.  
Attach the X cable chain/belt brackets to the ends of the X extrusions outside the motor plates.  Route the Z stepper and X stepper wires through the X Cable chain over to the Y stepper.  Route X, Y, and Z cables down the Y cable chain.  If you have the dual Y steppers, run the second Y stepper cables down the second Y cable chain.  
NOTE: The OpenSCAD files are very rough and require a STL of RotoScan's end bracket.  Open CableChainEnds.STL in netfabb or meshlab and remove all parts but the end piece you need.  Export that as a new STL and use it in OpenSCAD if you need to change the brackets.

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Double Hinged 12864 Full Graphics LCD Frame

title: TinyOLED - Improved  Version of Simple DIY Display Controller

description.text: This is an even tinier version of my TinyOLED display controller. Following a suggestion made by user Chri on the RepRap forum, I changed the position of the rotary encoder to stick out on the side instead of being on the front. This makes the use of the rotary encoder much more intuitive and allows an even smaller and simpler implementation of the display frame. Like for the first version, STL files are provided for display frames that fit the 0.96" and 1.3" versions of the 128x64 I2C OLED display, as well as the fully commented SCAD source. Also included is a PDF with the layout of the single sided PCB. For a more detailed description and further technical discussions see the original version of the TinyOLED and also the corresponding thread in the RepRap forum. Due to the right side mounting of the rotary encoder, this version only has a mounting hole for the double hinge mechanism on the left side of the display frame (for mounting on the right side of the printer). So for mounting the display on the left side of the printer, you need to rotate it by 180 degrees and configure the graphic driver to also rotate the display by 180 degrees.

The frames were printed from 3mm ABS filament on my DIY Prusa i3 using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.56mm extrusion width and 0.252 layer height. I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

comments.text: Could you share the rotary encoder you are using so that I can acquire one?  Also are you aware if this will run on the Smoothie.  I don't see the driver listed on the Smoothie site.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: It's just a simple standard EC11 type rotary encoder.  But it is mounted on a tiny piece of vertical PCB (2 of these are on the side of the PCB layout) which is soldered to the main PCB via 3 pin standard headers.

author: schooldrafting

description.text:
this glass will dump it contents if you attempt to drink from it (or if you fill it too high) trough a siphon.
though it does not do this very fast, maybe I'll add a foot to it so it'll go faster, like the "Tantalus Cup". the image is an x-ray view so you can see the internals (screenshot in cura) the solidworks file is fully parametric you can set the amount of tubes in the wall, the thickness of the tubes, the wall thickness, the height, bottom radius, top radius and possibly more. I might have made it a tad bit big ish...
So feel free to play around with those parameters (if you have solidworks) EDIT:
updated to a new V2 solidworks file and added a smaller (also thinner walls (0.7mm) and thinner airGap) STL V4 based on this file.
I'll remove the old solidworks file as one of the dimensions isn't driven by the formula as I had intended.

single thickness perimeter loops and a relatively high fill rate.
With 1mm wall thickness and my nozzle being .4 mm there is infill in-between the perimeters.however this appears not to be the case everywhere in the model, even though the thickness should be constant. the solidworks file names do not correspond to the STL file name.
the one I printed/am printing (currently) is not on here (the v1 STL), the v2 STL is slightly better.
those are all based on the first solidworks file.
The V2 solidworks file has the inserts that are the dividers between the tubes the scaled down by .05mm so they don't interfere with the mesh on the outside, I'm sure this has no practical use as it is mainly a visual artefact and causes the surface to be divided in different triangles but with equal quality, it also has the thickness and airGap paramters turned smaller etc but that is likely something you'll change if you download it anyway

comments.text: So how does this thing work?
comments.author: EdChamberlain

comments.text: wen you put a liquid inside once you pivot the cup to drink one of the tubes in the wall will overflow, as the exit of the tube is below the level of the liquid in the cup it will create a http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siphonhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S..., even if you lower the cup it should keep emptying out of the bottom.

title: Apple Watch portable Charger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pocket Sized battery powered charger for Apple Watch.  
it has a 2000mAh battery which should provide a good number of recharges of the watch.  It's self can be recharged using a micro USB cable.  
The circuit board is from Adafruit, 500c. I cut the Apple charge cable and directly soldered it to the 500c.  Red is +5v, white and green need to be shorted together, and shield is ground!

Print out the the 3 parts..place the battery in the lower box, and superglue to the middle section, pushing the battery cables through the hole.  
refer to the picture for the wiring of the switch etc.
